newsitem.title: USA: Conn. House passes racial school isolation bill.
newsitem.headline: Conn. House passes racial school isolation bill.

text.p: The Connecticut House of Representatives on Wednesday passed legislation aimed at correcting educational iniquities in the state's public schools.
The bill is a first step in addressing racial isolation and education quality issues that were the subject of the landmark Sheff vs. O'Neill lawsuit, Rep. Edna Garcia (D) said.
"I hope this legislation is the beginning of the end of racial isolation in our state's public schools," Garcia said.
The state supreme court last year ordered the legislature to find a remedy to the inferior schools and segregation that divides Hartford and its suburbs.
Hartford's schools serve some of the poorest children in the state. They score the lowest in the state on standardized tests.
Schools in Hartford are 95 percent black and Hispanic, compared to largely white and wealthier populations in the suburbs around the city.
Garcia said that in spite of her work on the bill, it did not achieve the full scope of what the court intended.
"It does not achieve the equalization of urban and suburban schools," she said. Neither does the bill provide a measurable standard for reducing racial, ethnic and economic isolation.
Funding for important parts of the legislation are vague, she said.
"(But) I believe we will fill in the gaps as we move forward on this important issue," Garcia said.
